Lurch,
 
 Why are Ernst Haeckel's "ontogeny recapitulates phylogeny" embryo drawings, (which were proven false in the 1880's) still in text books?

Originally posted by FreeThinker 
 Lurch,
 
 Why are Ernst Haeckel's "ontogeny recapitulates phylogeny" embryo drawings, (which were proven false in the 1880's) still in text books? 
 
 
 Usually as examples of errors, do you have a specific example?
 
 From TO 
  Regarding Futuyma's use of the Haeckel embryo drawings in the 3rd edition of Evolutionary Biology, Wells writes (p. 109), "But it was Futuyma who mindlessly recycled Haeckel's embryos in several editions of his textbook, until a 'creationist' criticized him for it." However, an inspection of Futuyma's 1st and 2nd editions of Evolutionary Biology reveals that no such drawings were included in these editions. In the first edition, Haeckel's biogenetic law and the problems with it are discussed on page 153 in respectable fashion (this corresponds with page 303 in the second edition) -- and in fact the primary issue surrounding Haeckel in textbooks, which has always been to debunk Haeckel's "ontogeny recapitulates phylogeny" oversimplification, is in fact admirably discussed in all three editions.

Life, Fourth Edition (copyright 2002) 
 
 The book does say that Haeckel took "a bit of artistic license" and that the drawings "did not represent scale" but says that "The data show that there really are similarities in embryonic structures, supporting the concept of common ancestry." Life also states: "Today most biologists reject the biogenetic law, as Haeckel's view is called" but they still use his drawings to show "similarities in embryonic structures"???
 
 Why do we need examples of error in our text books?
Examples of past errors give historical context and a view of how advances have been made.

Way back when I took embryology, the professor wrote on the board the first day of class, "Ontogeny recapitulates phylogeny." He then turned to the class and pointed to the words and said, "That is wrong. If any time during the progress of this course you begin to think that it may be correct, you are in danger of failing this course. You must see me immediately so that we can discuss the matter and you can correct your error." We then went on with a course in embryology.
 
 Actually, I don't know why the drawings were used in books long after it was known that they were wrong. Even Haeckel's contemporaries noticed that the drawings weren't correct and got him to admit it. I didn't think that they were actually used that much any more, at least not without comment. At least that was my experience. Perhaps I just had a better teacher than most. They became somewhat of a standard and probably were put in to the books because publishers were too lazy to change them. Maybe they didn't know any better. Shortly after Haeckel admited what he had done, Romanes used them in a book in 1901. I don't know if he was aware that the drawings were fudged, but they seem to have been picked up by text after text after that. Certainly, most examples I have seen in recent years do not represent Haeckel's drawings as correct. Why did Haeckel fudge the pictures? Maybe he thought he was on to something with his biogenetic law. Fudging the data can destroy a career today (unless you are a creation scientist).
 
 Richardson's paper in 1997 caused a stir. He told everyone what they should have already known, that Haeckel fudged the drawings. It is too bad that it wasn't made clearer that the drawings were wrong much earlier. I even found a page from a small college that claims that Richardson's paper corrected a major misunderstanding among developmental biologists and evolutionary biologists. I don't know that that is true. I don't recall ever hearing from any qualified biologist that wasn't aware of the fact that the pictures are wrong and the biogenetic law is wrong.
 
 In reality, the adult features of ancestors seldom appear as intermediate stages in the ontogeny of a descendant. What is closer to being true is that different descendants of a common ancestor are likely to share early embryonic characters with one another and, one presumes, with the common ancestor. However, various features develop at different rates in the descendants than they did in the ancestor. Thus, a coordinated appearance of the ancestral morphology is unlikely to be seen in the descendant.
 
 Also, preadult stages of an organism must grow and survive in their own environment. Therefore they may show characteristics that the ancestor didn't have, or they may not develop characteristics that would be a detriment.
 
 There is also the observation that in some cases it is a juvenile characteristic of the ancestor that appears in the descendant rather than an adult characteristic of the ancestor appearing in the juvenal. Just that is enough to falsify the biogenetic law.
 
 But I can tell you quite simply why your book says, "The data show that there really are similarities in embryonic structures, supporting the concept of common ancestry." It is because the data show that there really are similarities in embryonic structures, supporting the concept of common ancestry.
